bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Florence M. Read, September 17, 1921

div1.p: Hanson thanks Read for mail and the ruling regarding pay for campaign employees. He describes the difficulties doing field work during a workers' strike. He discusses reassignment of investigators to Panama.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Florence M. Read, September 17, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION
DE LA
CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EL LOS DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
---
OFICINA CENTRAL
-----
Trujillo,
September, 17, 1921.
Miss Florence M. Read,
Assistant Secretary,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York City,
My Dear Miss Read:
div1.p:
I thank for Your letter in regard to my cable from Panama
and the ruling in regard to the pay of the employees of the
campaign, Before leaving Chiclayo I replied to several letters
which had arrived during my absence, several of which were very
much delayed, written in May and June etc., For instance
since my arrival in Trujillo on the 15th of Sept. I have re-
ceived a letter from Dr. Carter written on the 16th of May. No
doubt Dr. Carter has wondered why I have not replied to this.

At present we are confronted with a rather annoying situ-
ation here. There is a general strike on in the entire Province
of Trujillo, as a results of which everything is tied up. There
are no trains running, none of the dock laborers are working,
the jitney drivers have gone out in sympathy with the rest and
we are practicably unable to move. The object of our coming
down on this trip was to make certain of our conditions in this
Province and the Department. I wanted Mr. Pickett and Mr. Dunn
to go over all the places where we had been working to give a
general report checking on the actual conditions of the day, but
with this bolshiviki condition existing we are going to be very
much handicapped in this frinal revision of Mr. Pickett's.

I had planned for Mr. Pickett to make a revision of all the
work down as far as the territory where Mr. Corrigan has been
working, but it appears doubteful that we shall be able to do
much under the existing conditions. Fortunately we had this
Department in such condition that we are not yet in any danger
and if conditions can be partially normalized within the next
week we shall still be safe. None of my forces have joined the
sympathetic strike, but our restricted movements handicapps us.

My plans have been for Mr. Pickett and Mr. Corrigan to re-
turn to their positions on the Canal Zone in the first part of
October. By that time I think we will have things in very good
conditions all along the coast. From that time on it will be a
case of “watchful waiting”, and it seems from the general atti-
tude of the people that it will be better not to attempt to con-
tinue the campaign any longer than is ansolutely necessary to
be certain of the results. By January we can speak more definitely
in regard to this matter.

In this letter I am enclosing a lest of Physicians and others
who I think may be interested in receiving a copy of the trans-
lation of Dr. Carter's lectures on Yellow Fever. From Chiclayo
I sent you a copy of the translation made by our Interpretor in
Chiclayo. In the list to which I refer above, The address is
given above and the names of the men to receive a reprint is g
indicated below.
